Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: I stared at my phone, my partner’s message glowing on the screen: “Can’t wait for our weekend together. I’ll miss you so much.” My heart ached, knowing this was our last chance to be together before he left for months. I wanted to savor every moment, to hold his hand and talk late into the night, to reassure him—and myself—that distance wouldn’t change us. But as I packed my bag, my phone buzzed again. This time, it was from the mosque committee: “The backup imam is still out of town. We’re counting on you to lead the prayers this weekend.” I felt the weight of their trust, the responsibility to guide the congregation, especially when so many relied on me for spiritual comfort. My mind spun with guilt and longing. How could I be present for my partner when my community needed me? How could I let down the people who looked to me for guidance? My heart pulled in two directions, each role demanding all of me, and I stood frozen, torn between love and duty, unable to choose.
